Especially disturbing to me is the part where the wife is brutally abusive to her paraplegic husband, physically, verbally, and emotionally. To be sure, he'd been a huge jerk to her and deserved it. But she was on the edge of losing control, and could have easily murdered him. It was vicious and ugly. I don't see any value in going that far in a movie, even if you're trying to be realistic; the scene could have shown her acting in a more responsible manner. As violent as our society has become, we shouldn't be showing that kind of ugliness.

This was my first Tyler Perry movie that I picked up quite by accident at my local video store (when there still were video stores) and I have seen just about every one of his movies and plays since.  It introduced the public to Medea, one of the funniest characters in recent history who makes repeat performances and delivers.  It was a romantic comedy, of course, but we have just enough comic relief and dramatics in it to make it something that mass appeals.  I am not the target audience for this (I'm a white woman in my 40s who has never been married nor do I have kids), but things spoke to me in this movie.

After 18 years of marriage, Helen is shocked and horrified that her husband Charles is ending their marriage and leaving her for a woman named Brenda who he has been cheating with and fathered two children with.  Kicked out of their house with no where to go, Helen takes her U-Haul truck (which Charles had packed for her with all her stuff) to her grandmother in the city of Atlanta, Medea.  Medea, a thuggish, rough gal, takes her in because even though they have not spoken to each other in many years, are still family.  Helen starts to rebuild her life slowly but surely, getting a job as a waitress and going through her divorce in court with Tyler Perry acting as her attorney.  There are some predictable things that go on (she and the driver of the U-Haul, Orlando, are going to fall for one another and give her a second chance at love) and some subplots (her attorney Brian is dealing with his drug addicted ex wife and his kids), but we are focused of course on Helen and her dealings with Charles.  Just when she is about to give her answer to Orlando in his proposal of marriage, she sees on the news that Charles had an accident and is confined to a wheelchair and goes to him.  She is, after all, still his wife and is legally responsible for him.  Charles has been abandoned by Brenda, along with all his money, and he realizes his mistakes with Helen.  Helen does forgive him, but she knows that their marriage is over once and for all and leaves for greener pastures.

This spoke to me on many levels, especially the relationship between Helen and Charles.  He is a self centered, greedy man who does not appreciate what he has until he makes a terrible mistake.  Instead of coming clean about his own faults, he lashes out at Helen with verbal and emotional abuse, both in the end of their marriage and when they are reunited after his accident.  I have seen this happen so many times with men.  Some argue that women go for Bad Boys as well.  Well yes, that's true, but just as many men try to make it work with trash instead of a good woman.  How many guys have I seen, young and old, leave their spouse or girlfriend, a good woman who is edgy, fun, hard working and exciting, for a trashy woman?  You as a man look pretty ridiculous if you leave your wife for a twenty year old stripper, I'm just saying.  This has happened to me more times than I care to think about now.  Fortunately I have never been married to these guys, but the next one who comes along they rebound to within six months to a year and they keep it dramatic and crazy.  One married another woman barely a year after he broke it off with me (after knowing each other for six weeks) to have her take advantage of him financially (moving to another state and buying a house there and paying for her daughter's education), and then leaving him for another man she was cheating on him with.  And I hear him say all the time that he made a terrible mistake in leaving me.  Yes, he did.  But this is something that I think a lot of women have to accept which is not pretty - that men want trash instead of a good woman.  Sounds bitter of me, but I have seen this in action too many times to think otherwise.

This 2005 film version of Tyler Perry's stage play, directed by Darren Grant gives viewers a complex look at the African American demographic in modern-day Atlanta through the eyes of a woman named Helen McCarter,played with skillful range by Kimberly Elise, with Perry himself in three roles as the sassy Madea, her brother, Joe, and Helen's cousin, Brian.
  We meet Helen and her attorney husband Charles(Steve Harris) on a grand night in Atlanta society where Charles receives an honor for his work. Despite the evening of toasts, tributes, compliments, and an evening on the ballroom floor, by the time Helen's husband drops her off at their mansion to return purportedly to his office, we know, as Helen ascends the porch stair case looking like a queen, that there are serious cracks in the facade.
 In the course of this film, we see Helen's attempt to salvage her troubled 18-year marriage met with spite and contempt from her husband, who has a new woman in his life named Brenda(Lisa Marcos), whom,as it happens, has already given him two children--a fact upon which Helen literally stumbles when she tries to have lunch with Charles at his office.
 Shortly thereafter, U-Haul worker Orlando,(played with great intelligence and sensitivity by Shemar Moore) witnesses the devastating scene of Helen being thrown out of her own house by Charles after a bitter confrontation with Charles and his mistress there. The U-Haul trailer is packed with Helen's things and Orlando is instructed to drop Helen off whereever she wants to go. After driving around for sometime, a still reeling and devastated Helen is asked to decide where to go by Orlando, who must get to his second job. She decides to go to her grandmother Madea's house, and this is where the comedy and the drama of the story will combine.
 When Helen arrives, she is also reunited with her cousin Bryan's estranged wife Debrah(Tamara Taylor), an addict to whom Madea is giving some food before sending her back on the street.
 Madea is naturally outraged by what has happened to her granddaughter, and the following day, goes with her to the mansion while Charles is out, and leads Helen in ripping up the mistresses' high fashion wardrobe. Charles and Brenda confront the two of them, and there is dramatic license taken in an outrageous scene with a chain saw, which lands both Helen and Madea in the slammer until they are bailed out by Brian.
  Placed under house arrest, Madea entertains family and friends at a gathering at her home where a woman named Mildred(Carol Mitchell-Leon) joins Uncle Joe in smoking reefer during a card game, and both see rabbits in a hallucination.
 Soon this is overshadowed as the guests line-dance to music, and Helen, wondering how to get her life back together, is reunited with Orlando and taking her bitterness out on him because he knows her shameful situation.
  Helen also visits her mother(Cecily Tyson), relegated to a nursing home, especially since Charles did not want any relatives around him. The religious elderly lady gives her daughter a gentle pep talk, encouraging her to tap into her own strength in the wake of her reversal of fortune. Amid hilarious moments of antagonism from Joe and Madea's sharp and riotous retorts, Helen takes a job as a waitress, and gradually finds some personal happiness. She sees Orlando again when he is a customer at the restaraunt where she works, and they gradually begin dating.
 In the meantime, a shady deal Charles made with a client slowly comes back to haunt him. In due time, his estranged wife's observation about how "God has the power to show you that He is God!" will be vindicated in a way in which he will never forget.
 We also follow Brian's family situation, having to raise two kids(Tiffany Evans, Avery Knight) by himself due to their mother's substance abuse, and Madea's urging him to let his daughter join their church choir, advising him that just because his wife's singing career led her to drug abuse does not mean the same will happen to his daughter.
 A dramatic turn of events sends Helen back to Charles just as Orlando was about to propose to her, and Charles will find that within those 30 days in which their divorce is to become  final, Helen is all he really has left. But for Helen, this is the occassion where 18 years of pent-up rage come to the foreground and her own personal version of what was referred to as "Operation Hell's Fury" in "The First Wives Club" is fully enacted.
 Madea's reflections on revenge are another high point of hilarity in the story. In the finale there is some reconciliation where there needed to be. But, ironically after a church service, the once mad black woman whose journalistic recordings are the staple of this story makes a dramatic decision with her life for which no one could honestly blame her.
 While many have complained about the sterotypical characters involved, this piece is one that depicts certain realities of life that take us through the whole gamut of human emotions with humor and style.

"Diary of a Mad Black Woman" is a flick about a couple who have been married for many years (played by Steve Harris and Kimberly Elise.)  On their wedding anniversary, the husband decides to tell his wife that he doesn't wish to be married to her any longer and that he found someone else.  In doing this, he is very curt, succinct and blatantly rude to her, even going as far as dragging her out of their home since she refused to leave.  Throughout the movie, the wife has a very difficult time copping with her husband's cruelty.  She is forced to move in with a family member, the always wild Mable "Madea" Simmons.  The wife pretty much remains composed, even after the breakup, but of course, with the help of Madea, she gives her husband a piece of her mind a few times, something he deserved.  She eventually finds someone else who is interested in her, but she is having a very difficult time with losing her husband.  Many of the scenes in this movie are quite emotional and heartfelt.  Some scenes aren't easy to watch.

The husband is shot in the movie and is temporarily paralyzed.  His new girlfriend no longer wants to be involved with him but his wife opts to take care of him, but she gives him quite a hard time in the process.  Near the end of the movie, she leads her husband to believe that she wants to reconcile and get back together, but in the end, she chooses the man who she was dating after her husband left her.

Kimberly Elise is a good actress but for some of the scenes in this movie, she was too reserved.  She should have been more explosive during certain scenes.  Steve Harris did a fantastic job with his role.  Shemar Moore also did well, as did Tyler Perry.

I recommend this movie for those who want to see a bittersweet movie with quite a few laughs.  It's a keeper.

The hooks draw you in. You immediately care for the black woman wronged. Madea's get mad and get even message from Tyler Perry in his fat suit. Tyler Perry as Joe cracking about Madea's "refrigerator in her behind". There's always a laugh around the corner.

What makes this film a little stronger than I expected was that it successfully draws on messages of black family without being aimed at a purely churchgoing audience. Sinners will smile a little bit more at some of their churched relatives. Saints will be moved by the struggles for salvation and forgiveness in the movie.

The plot is not always tight. There's a bit of heavyhanded foreshadowing at times and there's a sideplot with the lawyer's crack addict wife that probably adds some unnecessary running time. Still, I give Tyler credit. This is first time out of the box and I think that he learned a lot from this movie in making an even stronger Madea.

Tyler's an amazing entrepreneur and a caring playwright who makes a bold move in this movie. Check this one out and strongly consider buying it.

This was something special as we watch the saga of Helen unfold. She gets an unexpected surprise for her 18th anniversary, and then some from her husband, Charles! You will meet my two favorite characters in this, Madea and Joe, two of the craziest relatives you will ever want to meet, and want to love. Sometimes you have to rip things apart just to feel better, like Madea suggests. (watch the movie!) By the way, they are both played by Tyler Perry, as well as one other character, and YOU have to figure that one out for yourself. Let me give you a fair warning... once this has it's grip on you, don't try getting out! It won't work, ok?

This also has the powerful message of forgiveness, combined with unconditional love! Oh my goodness! As you can plainly see, I can't say enough about this. I think I'll go for a few more lines, amen? So while this have a moment or two of sadness, or the occasional "What the hell?", set them aside!! And when you see this at Blockbuster, or wherever you rent your movies, put aside your preconceptions about this until you actually WATCH IT! I probably should have, because I've been missing one of the best movies out there for about six months. Only get half a glass of beverage, and maybe half a bowl of popcorn, because they'll go flying when you start laughing, yet bring along some tissues, just in case. Now, quit reading this and go out and get it.

...at times this film made me want to. Of course I found problems with this film--namely the Madea caricature. Oftentimes, I felt as if I were watching two different films at once. And while Madea was only in a few scenes it was sometimes distracting from the seriousness of the plot. Another problem I had with the film was some of the dialogue. There is a line where the character Helen (played by Kimberly Elise) talks about her new beau Orlando (played by Shemar Moore) in a diary entry and mentions that not only is he beautiful and sensitive, but he's a Christian too! Quite frankly, it just sounded somewhat childish and ridiculous to me.  Oftentimes, I felt like I was watching a soap opera because some of the dialogue and scenes were so melodramatic and over the top (especially the overblown ending church scene, which left much to be desired) that I was wondering when they were going to bring in the violins--and in fact I think they actually did.  At times I felt that parts of the film were too contrived and maybe a little unrealistic.  I found it hard to believe that a man as drop dead gorgeous as Orlando (Shemar Moore) would be lured by or even be remotely interested in Helen (Kimberly Elise), or that a man SO good looking would be celibate, thoughtful, considerate, sensitive, understanding, or as insightful as he was.

But..on the other hand...

The film's cinematography was stunning--and the acting was top notch.  Kimberly Elise is not a favorite of mine but she is very talented and always delivers.  Steve Harris (The Practice) is highly convincing and does well with what he has to work with.  He is a VERY good actor and I hope he gets more opportunities in film.  Tyler Perry's no slouch and displays his acting chops (when he's not in drag or portraying some other caricature) very effectively and with ease.  And Tamara Taylor does her best with the material. But most astonishing, was Shemar Moore of all people, who actually CAN act (a little bit anyway..though I attribute some of his effectiveness to director Darren Grant). I remember when he was on the soap opera The Young and the Restless and my roommates in college would just swoon over him.  I on the other hand, just saw him as another pretty boy with no acting ability whatsoever getting by solely on good looks.  Times change.  And while I personally still find him highly annoying, his performance as the sensitive and understanding blue collar worker who falls for Helen IS believable.  He made me want to believe in fairy tales (well...at least where he was concerned anyway). I hope in the future he (Shemar Moore) becomes more mature and chooses more challenging roles where he can rely on his talent and not on his good looks.

Overall I thought this film had some serious limitations, but when I got the film I wasn't expecting a masterpiece--if I wanted that I would have gotten Gone With the Wind.  But for better or worse, this film kind of had a magic to it and for some inexplicable reason...I like it.

The film revolves around the character of Helen McCarter, and her abusive marriage to a one time drug dealer-turned lawyer. He gets a girlfriend and kicks her out of the house...after 20 years of marriage. Thru her cousin (played by Tyler Perry), she befriends a handsome young man that sweeps her off her feet. Before the film ends, her husband gets confined to a wheelchair. His girlfriend leaves him and he needs his wife to take care of him...which she does, unwillingly. She wants revenge and gets malicious on him (He's paralyzed from the neck down). She then learns from her mother and grandmother (also played by Tyler Perry), that she needs to forgive him. She does. All seems well, especially after they all attend church together, and seemingly start anew. After church they're all at the grandmother's house having a nice soul-food meal, and she get's up and tells her husband she's in love with another man, and walks out the door. The film ends with her in her new lover's arms. Now, if this is what Tyler Perry thinks is a Christian message of a movie, then I've got news for him!? The Bible says that a Christian woman that has an unbelieving husband, should stay with him and be submissive. Her Godly and Loving character may just save him. Nowhere does it say that we should leave to go find a 'better' lover. It does say a man can put away his wife, but it's not taught as the best thing to do.

 Not only that, but parts of this film were very vulgar and distasteful. It's not really what you'd want your children to watch. Drug usage, shooting, sexual innuendos...not really a family film. There were some very funny scenes, and much of it was entertaining ( i don't know which came first, this or the Nutty Professor films, but one of them is a rip-off of the other...at least Eddy Murphy didn't use Christianity as a crutch). Overall, i cannot recommend this one.  You'd be better off watching something else.

I am African American. I was born in 1954, and I graduated from USC in Los Angeles.  I feel I have a fairly firm grasp on reality.  My father was a career soldier when I was born, and we live a Middle Class/working class lifestyle.  My neighborhoods were predominately white since I was born.  In the 60s, this was a privilege for blacks, Hispanics, and other minorities.  We were the first groups to have "governmental protection," and had more choices than being Uncle Tom or Aunt Jemima.  I remember well the difference between acting black or acting white.  I guess I acted white.  To me it was just a communication tool.  But it was well accepted wherever I was.  I did not betray my race.  I was just who I was.  And I know of many African Americans (some in my parent's families) who REALLY acted black, like Madea (Tyler Perry's cross-dressing character).  And I LOVE them.  Church, aggressive behavior, strong family ties, all this is black culture, without the whitewash.  I applaud Mr. Perry for an entertaining/informative take on African-American culture that includes everyone you are likely to find in the "black community," (which continually widens and deepens) and gives credibility to both old school and new school black America.

I went into this movie not expecting much -- I just wanted something to watch -- but I came away having had a really good time.  The film can be a little too saccharine at times, which is why I gave it only 4 stars, but it also has a lot of heart to it.  In addition, it has something you don't see in movies these days, a strong sense of faith that doesn't beat you over the head or condescend.  My hat goes off to Tyler Perry for writing such a wonderful faith-based (if I can use that term) story without getting too preachy.  Perry also deserves kudos for creating two very wonderful, though over the top, characters in Madea and Joe.  The real breakout of this film has to be Kimberly Elise who has starred in two very good films in the last year:  first with "Woman Thou Art Loosed" and now with "Diary of a Mad Black Woman."  Elise really shines in her role and becomes the emotional and moral center of the entire film.  Yeah, this film can be a little too sickly-sweet, but it's also a lot of fun, a lot of heart, and well worth seeing more than once.

I felt every emotion Helen had and was involved in her characters' story Watch out Halle, Angela, Gabrielle and Viveca, Kimberly Elise is an up and comer. Looking at the extra features section on the making of, Diary of a Mad Black Woman I was surprised to find out there are special effects in this film. A Shawn James Essential Five star video. Please, Please pick this one up for your collection. In fact pick one up to give to friends and family as a gift you will not be disappointed and they won't be disappointed.

'Diary of a Mad Black Woman' may be the best African-American film since 'Waiting to Exhale'. You will love the script that is very well written by Tyler Perry.

You have this woman (Helen) who is abused physically and mentally by a Black Attorney of the Year in Atlanta. He is rich. You will love the mansion. What a mansion! Helen is kicked out for a white woman who he is secretly courting with his kids. In the process, the Uhaul driver is Shemar Moore's character who also works at a steel mill.

Ironically, Helen is very forgiving and lets him have his way in the divorce proceedings. But she really has not moved on. Shemar Moore loves her, woos her, and proposes to her. He like her has been left by another person in a marriage (a NFL football star). You will like how she finds out she is engaged. I can't spoil it, so you must watch and find out: Very unconventional but sweet.

And then the un-expected happens to the Attorney character. His demons catches up with him in the form of an old Afro-American male friend. And the Attorney is left in a coma.

Christine, his new love of his life, wants him to be allowed to die for obvious reasons. But Helen comes to the hospital as the wife to fight for his life, after being interrupted in the midst of a proposal by a news report of the attorney on tv. This leaves the proposal in limbo because she decides to be a good christian and help his get back on his feet. And comes a lot of anger and it is psycho-tic like, scary, but he asked for it from Helen.

In the midst, he changes his life 360 degrees and see who his real friends are and who really loves him, beyond just the marriage/affair situation. He gives his life to Christ. Repents for all the things he has done. Helen repents also for her mini-rage. So at the end you cannot really tell who Helen will marry. Trust me, unless someone has already told you the ending, you will not know who she will be with. And so I leave you with this clift hanger to watch the film!

Tyler Perry, an above average playwright, found his niche in black theatrical plays. Cashing in the millions from predominately black audiences. Diary is Perry's first jump from the stage to the big-screen. I'll try to keep my review as realistic and honest as possible here.

The Positives.

1. Diary as well as the rest of Perry's plays has always preached the positives of having strength in family, community, and in self.

2. All of the ultimate messages displayed are great morals all grafted or inspired from the Holy Bible. The film is loaded with plenty of biblical/Christian undertones.

3. Shemar Moore refrains from taking off his shirt for once.

The Negatives.

Despite the positive qualities of this film. The negatives send this one spiraling down like an albatross. This film is overloaded with countless and redundant stereotypes that plague many of today's "black" films and television shows. At times I felt like I was watching an old Minstrel Show minus the blackface paint. The comedy unveiled in Diary is extremely poor and one dimensional. For Media to be the inspirational/spiritual grandmother, she contradicts her elegance by overly pulling out hand guns on relatives, friends, and innocent bystanders. Don't get me wrong, I chuckled at the gun scenes...but it wasn't that funny. It's just sad when you have to get a roar out of your audience by adding on gun play to a bland/unoriginal joke. The scenes with her brother smoking weed with the other relatives could have been left out as well. For this to be a Christian oriented film, the protagonists often contradict themselves and their "holiness". None of the actors and actresses convinced me. Kimberley Elise was gaining a lot of momentum as an upcoming black actress on the scene, and kills that momentum here. She simply doesn't add flavor to this bad exploitation movie. At times Diary makes you feel like your watching a cheesy soap opera on UPN. It saddens me that many of our people (yes I'm a brotha) buy into this mess in the 21st century. It's like these Madia plays are sending us back 30 years. You can respond with the oh so common "it's just a film lighten up" stuff. But how much longer are we going to keep tolerating this nonsense. Diary is supposed to be uplifting but it brings us right back down time after time. The acting was horrific. Note, if Shamar Moore is casted in a film, chances are you're watching a bad movie.

It seems as if a majority of our (black/African-American) films are illustrated on these unrealistic canvases. Always a struggle between the filthy rich and the filthy poor in unrealistic settings. And in the midst of these films the people in the middle are never highlighted. "Black" films need more avant-garde substance in today's cinema. The clich' black church ending pretty much did it for me, which was stolen right from the Color Purple. Recently, I saw Kimberly Elise' Woman Thou Art Loose, and I was so taken by her performance. Diary of a Mad Black Woman is the perfect star showcase vehicle for Elise to demonstrate her dramatic range with a performance that requires her to shed a bucket of tears, get mad and get even with her nasty husband, forgive and let go, and fall in love again. This film instantly reminded me of Angela Bassette's Waiting To Exhale, but it's funnier, because Tyler Perry was totally funny. His portrayal of Madea is the comic relief to this touching dramedy.

Kimberly Elise(Helen), a loving housewife gets humiliated and kicked out by her self-center and successful lawyer husband(Charles/Steve Harris) whom she had been married to for 18 years. He had been secretly having a relationship with a white woman who had two kids with him. Helen had been mistreated by him a great deal, and she even had two miscarriages. She was devastated and had to go and stay with her tough and fierce grandmother Madea(Tyler Perry). Madea took her back to her husband's mansion and did some serious damage to the place, and they got arrested.

Orlando(Shemar Moore), a friend of Brian(Tyler Perry), who is Helen's cousin eventually become romantically involved with her. He had been on a rebound from a bad breakup and instantly related to the pain she was going through, and they bonded intimately. She was so happy for the first time that she was gradually falling in love again. All of a sudden, Charles gets shot by his vengeful client in the courtroom, and he was bed ridden for days. His money greedy mistress took all his money and abandoned him, leaving him in the care of Helen. She came back to get even with him, and she tortured him for days before forgiving him. He then realized that he must change and redemn himself.

Tyler Perry also played Grand Daddy Joe, the least striking role out of the three that he played. Tamara Taylor gave a scene-stealing performance as Brian's drug addict wife on the road to recovery. The sexy hunk Shemar Moore had some touching and romantic moments with Elise, and he's come a long way since The Young and The Rest. The gospel singing scene was very spiritually empowering. This film really delivered the message of only through the power of God can help you forgive sometimes.

When Helen's husband of 18 years decides he doesn't need her anymore, Helen must overcome not only her anger and rage but must learn what it is to truly love.  From this beginning, Diary of a Mad Black Woman goes on a wild tale that goes through many different sub genres of comedy.  There's some slapstick, low brow comedy, witty dialogue and even a touch of dark comedy toward the end.

Writer Tyler Perry creates a terrific vehicle to play three roles by himself.  By far the best role in here for him is Madea, Helen's semi-crazy aunt (I think?).  Madea's parts are the funniest portions of the movie, using everything from her gun to a chainsaw to prove a point.  Her over the top behaviour is perfect in setting the tone of the movie.  And considering Madea is a big character in Tyler's plays, I have a feeling we'll be seeing more of her.

Sometimes, though, Tyler's roles have an Eddie Murphy Klumps feel to them, especially Joe, an elderly man who is still infatuated with younger women.  His suggestions that he has viagra etc are directly in line with the Klumps style humor.  I wish he would have not created a character similar to those in that movie so he could stand on his own.  But, overall, it was all very funny.

Toward the end, the movie started reaching for cliches and melodrama.  The final scene in the church is a bit over the top for me.  That said, it's a great date movie.  There's enough laughs and tears for everyone that those who want to just laugh will laugh and those that like to cry at the end of a happy/sappy movie will also enjoy it.

I don't normally enjoy romantic films, I'm the first to admit it.  The genre has been filled with too many cliches and over the top moments that I can't usually get into them.  And yet I enjoyed this film for the most part.  With some of the exceptions above (especially the final church scene), I thoroughly enjoyed this movie.  Sure, sometimes it gets a little heavy handed and cliched but it still is one of the best romantic comedies I have seen in a long while.

Adapted from a Tyler Perry stage play, "Diary of a Mad Black Woman" is the story of Helen McCarter (Kimberly Elise), a polished, pampered, too-naive-to-be-true wife that has been forced onto the road of self-discovery and spiritual awareness, after being thrown out of her home by her husband of 18 years, Charles (Steve Harris), a highly successful, ironfisted defense attorney, in order to make room for Charles' mistress/mother of his illegitimate children (Lisa Marcos). While on her journey, she receives a little help from her mother (Cicely Tyson) and not-so-polished family from the 'hood, headed up by her lewd, crude, pistol-packing grandmother, Madea (Perry in drag).

The impact of Helen's plight would have been just as strong with less than half of the melodrama-turned-wackiness that you're subjected to in the first 20 minutes of the film. Admittedly, Steve Harris is rather convincing as a rat bastard, but that's precisely the problem, because we never learn just *what* it is that Charles is so mad about, which makes his WAY over-the-top enmity towards his lovely, docile, submissive wife of 18 years, cartoonish. Charles' behavior towards Helen wouldn't be totally unbelievable without reason, and Perry has a golden opportunity to give the characters some depth and the film some body by setting the stage for Helen and Charles' breakup, but he squanders this opporunity in lieu of clearing a platform for the Antichrist that has taken on the form of a Black male.

As fate would have it, Helen and her clothes end up being carted away from her Atlanta mansion and shambles of a marriage by Orlando (Shemar Moore).  Orlando is a divorced factory worker (his wife left him for a professional athlete because he didn't make enough money) whose Christian, handsome (in a rough-around-the-edges kind of way), chiseled, kind-spirited, charming, sensitive, sympathetic, patient, understanding, forgiving, affectionate, celibate, and immovable, where winning Helen over is concerned.  The only things he's missing are wings and a halo.

Helen's a Christian woman who feels compelled to remain committed to her marriage, after extenuating circumstances render her husband paralyzed, helpless, and alone. (The twist is that vengeance creeps in and eventually becomes every bit as much a motivator for Helen as her religious convictions.)  This causes Orlando to flinch, but only because Helen completely disappears from his life without explanation, and then refuses to make a decisive choice about her future with him upon reappearing.

There are a couple of subplots regarding Charles' dark background and a cousin, Brian (played by Perry out of drag), a responsible father dealing with an estranged wife struggling with a drug addiction, that I'm guessing were thrown in to add 'balance' to the film, but they're not very well thought out and as a result, rather uninspiring.  The final scene of the movie is a blatant rip-off of the final scene in "An Officer and a Gentleman".  The film has it's funny moments (and I do mean moments), but overall... inflammatory, hypocritical, sappy, a smorgasboard of stereotypes, and the comedy is predictable, regardless of whether you're familiar with Perry's previous workings or not.

I will give Tyler Perry credit for this much...he knows precisely where his bread is buttered.  For those who may not be at all familiar with his work, Perry is a highly successful, wildly popular playwright with an inspiring rags-to-riches story of his own to tell and, to his credit, a list of "Comedy/Drama/Gospel" hybrid stage plays that have grossed probably hundreds of millions of dollars by now and are attractive to a devoted following of predominantly church-going Blacks in America, the majority of them women.  Hence all of the eyes-wide-shut heaps of praise for this *clearly* bad movie that couldn't get a dime to eat if it wasn't of Black people, by Black people and for Black people.

This isn't by any stretch of imagination a masterful piece of cinema, and (dare I say it) it isn't intended to be. It's merely something to get Perry's feet wet in the big screen arena, and to keep the flock hyped until the collection plate makes it around to their pew.  And it's intended to be precisely what it tells you it is...a battering ram "for every Black woman that was ever done wrong by a Black man"... nothing more, nothing less.  So if you're not willing to shift your brain into neutral, or you're not a Black woman (mad or otherwise) and you're not a Tyler Perry fan.....then I suggest that you skip this one.  If you're looking for something truly "inspirational" and you don't already have them in your collection, I'd recommend "Antwone Fisher" and "Coach Carter".
